repnme.cdata!:
Chile and Colombia - Life-Long Learning and
            Training Project, Science for the Knowledge Economy Project,
            and Higher Education, Improving Access Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Performance Assessment
            Report (PPAR) covers three recently completed projects for
            the Chile and Colombia. Ratings for the Lifelong Learning
            and Training Project, and Science for the Knowledge Economy
            Project, for Chile were as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was significant,
            bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Higher Education, Improving Access Project for Colombia
            were as follows: outcome was satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, bank performance was
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons included: student loans may be an
            effective instrument to curb student dropout rates in higher
            education and increase learning. An impact evaluation of the
            project suggests this strongly by comparing drop-out rates
            of beneficiaries with those of otherwise similar
            non-beneficiaries. Since beneficiaries were generally poor,
            the program also improved equity through lowering dropout
            rates. However, as drop-out rates remain high, addressing
            student drop-out rates may need other actions, including
            adequate remedial programs and counseling. A better design
            may focus more strongly on accreditation of providers, while
            relying more on providers to identify the demand for skills
            by firms and the demand for technical education and training
            by students and workers.

repnme.cdata!: Chile - Lifelong Learning and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Lifelong Learning and
            Training Project for Chile were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: lifelong learning and training is crucial both
            from equity and efficiency perspectives. In the context of
            Chile's lifelong learning and training system, the
            development of human capital is solidly grounded in the
            country's needs to support its integration into the
            world economy as well as its social deficit. An adequate
            lifelong learning and training system necessarily involves
            diverse players that are in themselves heterogeneous, both
            in the public and private spheres. The success of Chile
            Califica was not the result of having a strong champion with
            high visibility within the public or private spheres who
            advocated for the development of a lifelong learning and
            training system. Rather, it was the result of gradually
            introducing an overall framework that addressed many of the
            weaknesses in the existing educational and training system
            in a comprehensive and integrated manner. Although the
            implementation of the project at the regional level resulted
            in added complexity, it ensured its relevancy at the
            regional level. While other developing countries can
            certainly learn from this innovative project, Chile's
            special characteristics mean that these ideas cannot be
            exported easily or wholesale.

1003184.trustfund:
TF040303-CHILE - VOCATIONAL AND TRAINING
            EDUCATION PROJECT,TF040262-CHILE - VOCATIONAL AND TRAINING
            EDUCATION PROJECT,TF026529-PHRD-CHILE: LIFELONG LEARNING

repnme.cdata!: Chile - Lifelong Learning and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Lifelong Learning and Training
            Project will assist the Government of Chile in laying the
            foundation for an articulated, and extended learning, and
            training system, with the participation of the private
            sector. Through its four main components, the project will:
            1) finance the promotion for an increased private-public
            supply of basic, and secondary education opportunities for
            adults, which includes the establishment of a learning
            assessment, and certification system for adults, as well as
            that of new modules to encompass adult basic, and secondary
            education along with training, and distance learning; 2)
            finance, through a competitive Fund, vertical articulation
            of technical secondary, with tertiary technical-professional
            education, through the establishment of technological
            curricular disciplines. As well, the horizontal articulation
            of technical secondary, and tertiary education with the
            labor market, will be constituted through regional networks
            of educational institutions at the technical, secondary, and
            tertiary levels. Access to, and quality of education will be
            improved through pre- and in-service teacher training
            institutions; 3) establish a national system of competency
            framework, and professional-vocational pathways on selected
            sectors of the economy, and, four proactive learning, and
            training management information systems will be financed;
            and, 4) finance a national Project Coordination Unit, and in
            addition, support the strengthening of the national, and
            regional Training and Employment Service (SENCE), by
            financing computers, and equipment, training, and technical
            assistance, while a continuous communication, and
            dissemination strategy will be maintained.
